author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: Music From the Sole Brings a Party to the Joyce Theater
description: The group, led by Leonardo Sandoval and Gregory Richardson, leans into tap’s oneness of dance and music for “I Didn’t Come to Stay.”
content: The Joyce Theater has rarely felt as electric as it did on Tuesday, when 14 musicians burst through a door at the back of the house, singing and drumming as they paraded through the audience toward the stage. Within seconds, the crowd was clapping and cheering, some people on their feet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Alec Baldwin Pleads Not Guilty to Involuntary Manslaughter
description: Mr. Baldwin was indicted by a grand jury months after the dismissal of an earlier criminal charge against him in the death of a cinematographer on the set of “Rust.”
content: Alec Baldwin pleaded not guilty to a charge of involuntary manslaughter on Wednesday, following a grand jury indictment that revived the criminal case against him for the fatal shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the film “Rust” in 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: This Ancient Fish Gave the Whole Ocean the Stiff Lower Lip
description: What paleontologists long believed were long spines on the aptly named Alienacanthus turn out to be an extended lower jaw.
content: Some 375 million years ago, armored fishes ruled a watery world. Known as placoderms, these primitive jawed vertebrates came in all shapes and sizes, from small bottom-dwellers to giant filter-feeders. Some, like the wrecking-ball-shaped Dunkleosteus, were among the ocean’s earliest apex predators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: E.U.’s Hungary Problem Looms Large Ahead of Crucial Ukraine Summit
description: Hungary has again broken with its peers on support for Ukraine. This time, the E.U. may have had enough.
content: European Union leaders meet in Brussels on Thursday, hoping to approve a landmark multibillion euro fund for Ukraine that will help keep the country afloat for the next four years, no matter what happens on the battlefield, or in the U.S. Congress threatening to cut support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams and Mike Ives
title: Melinda Wilson, 77, Who Helped Brian Wilson Through Mental Illness, Dies
description: “She was my savior,” Mr. Wilson, the Beach Boys visionary, said of his wife of 28 years. Their relationship was portrayed in the 2014 film “Love & Mercy.”
content: Melinda Wilson, who helped rescue her future husband, Brian Wilson, the chief musical architect and visionary of the Beach Boys, from a decades-long psychological spiral when they began dating in the 1980s, died on Tuesday at their home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Coral Davenport
title: Biden Picks John Podesta to Be His New Global Climate Representative
description: Podesta, a veteran political strategist and presidential adviser on clean energy, will succeed John Kerry, who is stepping down after three years.
content: President Biden has tapped John Podesta, his adviser on clean energy and a seasoned political strategist, to succeed John Kerry as his global representative on climate, the White House confirmed on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Who Should Interpret the Rules? Congress, Courts or Agencies?
description: Responses to a column and a guest essay about a case before the Supreme Court. Also: Renouncing Donald Trump; Jan. 6 and the young; Palestinian life.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitra Taj
title: What Is Going on at Machu Picchu?
description: Protesters blocked access to the Incan site in Peru over a new ticketing system. Tourists have been evacuated, but there could be more unrest. Here’s what to know.
content: Hundreds of tourists were stranded near Machu Picchu, Peru’s most-visited site, over the weekend after demonstrators blocked railway and bus routes to the site and shut down local shops and restaurants in Aguas Calientes, the gateway to Machu Picchu, in the country’s Cuzco region. Some visitors posted videos on social media pleading for help. The police evacuated about 700 tourists on Saturday. Many left without seeing the site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Lively and Elegant and Not at All Dry Chicken Breasts
description: Pierre Franey’s classic, quick recipe yields juicy white meat in an assertively lemony sauce.
content: Getting chicken breasts right is a flex, but a tricky one. The delicate white meat, so low in fat, can go from supple to chalky in only one distracted, phone-checking, heartbreaking minute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: What Murder Mysteries Solve
description: The books offer the promise of an ending where all questions are answered and some sort of justice is done.
content: At the beginning of December, I turned to whodunit fiction as a respite from the accumulated exhaustion of a long year, and the more recent stresses of writing about the horrors of the war in Israel and Gaza. But why, if that was my purpose, would I find solace in such an inherently violent genre?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Colin Moynihan
title: 5 Takeaways From the Sotheby’s Art Fraud Trial
description: The inner workings of the art market were explored during the trial, which ended with Sotheby’s cleared of any role in what a Russian oligarch said was a scheme to defraud him.
content: Over the course of three weeks, the art world watched as a Russian oligarch pursued a lawsuit in an American court in which he accused Sotheby’s of abetting a fraud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: An Impeachment Push, and a Militia’s Surprise Move
description: Plus, broadcasting layoffs on TikTok.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosa Lyster
title: The Power of Cute: Sweet, Cuddly and Taking Over the World
description: There is plenty of fun and truly adorable stuff in “Cute,” a new exhibition in London. But there are some creepy and unsettling things, too.
content: Try this: Ask someone you know to define “cute.” They are not allowed to simply give an example of a cute thing, so no babies or sweet little rabbits singing a song about being brave; they must try and give a definition for the adjective itself. See how long it takes before words give way to gestures (hands making clutching motions, arms squeezing tightly around invisible teddy-bear-size objects) or inarticulate noises (cries of anguished delight, high-pitched vowel sounds). See how long it takes before they are scrunching up their faces in what looks a lot like pain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Interest Rate Cuts Could Be a Boon to Biden
description: The Federal Reserve is independent of the White House, but lower rates could improve the president’s standing among voters.
content: Federal Reserve officials do not set interest rates with presidential elections in mind. In fact, the central bank is independent of the White House and, as the Fed chair, Jerome H. Powell, has said repeatedly, the institution takes that independence seriously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni and Dionne Searcey
title: Unlikely Allies Want to Bar a Brazilian Beef Giant From U.S. Stock Markets
description: Environmentalists and American meat producers alike are asking regulators to keep JBS, the world’s biggest meatpacker, off the New York Stock Exchange.
content: A giant Brazilian meatpacking company is facing persistent opposition to its plans for a listing on the New York Stock Exchange because of concerns about corruption settlements, accusations of Amazon deforestation and its growing market share in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: The Messenger to Close After Less Than a Year
description: By closing less than a year after it launched, The Messenger is now one of the biggest busts in the annals of online news.
content: The Messenger, a news website that pledged to shake up the media industry with a playbook borrowed from the doomed publishing start-ups of yesteryear, will be closing down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Marche
title: Everybody Is Talking About A.I. What the Heck Is It, Anyway?
description: A guide to the best books about artificial intelligence.
content: Much of the current discourse about artificial intelligence sucks. A.I. is one of those subjects that seem to appear out of nowhere, blotting out everything else — like the sun rising over the desert — and a mixture of ludicrous hype and vacuous panic has rushed in to shade the blinding dazzle. A.I. is going to transform every industry, or it’s going to end the world, or both, and you need to know which now. Meanwhile, accurate answers to basic questions — What even is it? How does it work? Where did it come from? Where is it going? — tend to be tucked away in dry technical language that borders on the incomprehensible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Why Bedrooms Aren’t Just for Sleeping Anymore
description: Maybe you’re working from home more often — or you need a place to retreat from the world. Here’s how to make your bedroom do double (or triple) duty.
content: Making the most of whatever space you have is just good sense — whether you’ve recently bought your dream home or, like many people, are staying put until the housing market calms down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Rescuing the Holocaust From Distortion and Cliché
description: A new book by the historian Dan Stone seeks to amend — and expand — our understanding of the genocide.
content: “The Holocaust teaches us nothing”: It’s a surprising declaration to encounter in the early pages of “The Holocaust: An Unfinished History,” not least because its author, Dan Stone, also happens to be the director of the Holocaust Research Institute at the University of London. But Stone is doing what a conscientious historian does, countering platitudes with demystification.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: Get Your Cholesterol in Check
description: It’s critical for preventing heart disease and other serious health problems.
content: While 86 million adults in the United States have high cholesterol levels, one third of Americans say they haven’t had their numbers checked in the last five years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Can a Piano Capture the Grandeur of Rachmaninoff’s Symphonic Music?
description: Inon Barnatan has created a solo transcription of “Symphonic Dances” in which he tries “not to imitate an orchestra, but to embody it.”
content: Sergei Rachmaninoff composed two versions of “Symphonic Dances,” his last major work. One was the grand, orchestral score most often performed today; the other, a piano duet.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 31, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Jan. 31, 2024.
content: An article on Sunday about a lack of support for Nikki Haley in her home state of South Carolina misstated when Ms. Haley resigned as governor of South Carolina to serve in Donald J. Trump’s administration. It was seven years ago, not eight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A New Gig in the Science World
description: Jennifer Raab, the former president of Hunter College, is now heading the New York Stem Cell Foundation.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll meet the new president and chief executive of a foundation that backs stem cell research. We’ll also get details on a $5 million fine in a New Jersey tax break scandal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Zuckerberg turns to face abuse victim families: ‘I’m sorry for everything you have all been through.’
description: The Meta chief executive addressed families during a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on child online safety.
content: Mark Zuckerberg stood to directly address relatives of online child abuse victims in the Senate gallery on Wednesday, a first for the chief executive of Meta and a singular moment in a morning full of tense exchanges during a Judiciary Committee hearing on child safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Stream These 11 Movies Before They Leave Netflix in February
description: “Dune” and “Snowpiercer” are among the action epics, dramas and teen comedies leaving soon for U.S. subscribers. Watch them while you can.
content: Family fun, action epics, historical dramas, teen comedy — there’s a little something for everyone among the titles leaving Netflix in the United States in February. (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: Walmart to Add 150 U.S. Stores in Five-Year Expansion Drive
description: The retail giant, which last opened a domestic location in 2021, said most of the stores would be newly built.
content: Walmart will add 150 stores in the United States over the next five years, a major expansion drive for the retail giant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Dick Traum, 83, Dies; Marathoner Championed Disabled Athletes
description: The first to complete a marathon with a prosthetic leg — he did it in New York — he went on to found a track club for disabled runners, expanding it worldwide.
content: Dick Traum, who was regarded as the first person to run a marathon on a prosthetic leg, finishing New York’s race in 1976, and who went on to found the Achilles Track Club to encourage other disabled athletes in an era when they faced barriers to participation in sports, died on Jan. 23 in Manhattan. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses and Orlando Mayorquin
title: Man Is Charged With Killing His Father After Posting Grisly YouTube Video
description: A disturbing video in which a man claims he is holding his dead father’s head was available on YouTube for about five hours on Tuesday night.
content: A man who posted a graphic video on YouTube in which he claimed to be holding his father’s severed head was charged with murder and abuse of a corpse early Wednesday after his father’s body was found in a Pennsylvania home, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Feud: Capote vs. the Swans’ Review: Cold Blooded
description: In FX’s series about Truman Capote’s downfall, there’s nothing waiting at the rainbow’s end.
content: “Feud: Capote vs. the Swans,” which premieres Wednesday on FX (streaming on Hulu), is something that its protagonist could not abide: a bore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: ‘Gilmore Girls’ Is an Endless Buffet of TV Comfort Food
description: The show, which ended in 2007, was still one of the 10 most-watched shows across major streaming platforms last year, according to the research firm Nielsen.
content: Some things have inexplicable staying power. The Hermès Birkin bag. Cheetos. Crocs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: The True Price of Apple’s $3,500 Vision Pro Is Closer to $4,600
description: The new headset teaches a valuable lesson about the cost of tech products: The upsells and add-ons will get you.
content: When Apple unveiled the Vision Pro virtual reality goggles last year at a technology conference, many in the audience gasped at the price: $3,500. That’s more than quadruple the cost of a new iPhone and 14 times the cost of a competing headset from Meta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: The Queer Kids Are All Right. And Now They’re Making Me Better.
description: How watching gay coming-of-age stories has helped repair a heart still stuck in the past — and still scarred by a less welcoming world.
content: Here’s a list of every openly queer person I knew when I was 15:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Senators Grilled Tech Executives on Child Safety
description: Also, the Fed is not quite ready to cut borrowing rates. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: Five of the country’s most prominent tech executives appeared at a hearing today on Capitol Hill, where they were berated by lawmakers for creating “a crisis in America” by ignoring the spread of child sexual abuse material on their platforms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Dominus
title: Recruited to Play Sports, and Win a Culture War
description: Many New College athletes had no idea they were part of Ron DeSantis’s attack on “woke ideology.” Then the semester began.
content: They came to be somewhere sunny and warm. Some came because their parents lived nearby; others came from far away — from abroad — because it was a way to study in the United States. Madison Garcia, a softball player who previously attended Lincoln University, a historically Black college in Missouri, came because she was lonely and cold in the Midwest. The school recruiting Garcia and the others, New College of Florida, offered all freshmen free laptops, which was a nice perk. But the main reason most of the athletes showed up for the very first season of varsity sports at New College was that someone there was offering them the chance to keep doing what they loved. “I would do anything to be on that field,” said Nahuel Garcia, a freshman soccer player from Miami. “I’ll be water boy. I’ll be ball boy. It’s like, I need soccer in my life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Taking Off
description: Nathan Hale makes his New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Ukraine and Russia Exchange Hundreds of Prisoners of War
description: The swap came a week after the crash of a Russian military transport plane that Moscow said was carrying Ukrainian prisoners.
content: Russia and Ukraine announced the exchange of hundreds of prisoners of war on Wednesday, resuming the carefully choreographed trading of captives only a week after Moscow accused Kyiv of shooting down a Russian military transport plane that it said was carrying dozens of Ukrainian prisoners of war on their way to be exchanged.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 30, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Jan. 30, 2024.
content: An article on Saturday about a United Nations investigation of claims that employees participated in the Oct. 7 attack misstated the number of people working for UNRWA. The agency has 13,000 employees in Gaza alone, not across the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Can Biden Take a Page Out of Trump’s Playbook?
description: The prize in the struggle over the border is the 2024 presidency and all the power that goes with it.
content: In a bid to weaken Donald Trump’s domination of the immigration crisis going into the 2024 election, President Biden has reversed his position and adopted a high-risk strategy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Thursday Briefing: Iran Is ‘Not Looking for War’
description: Also, a coming E.U. decision on Ukraine funding.
content: The head of Iran’s Revolutionary Guards said yesterday that the country was “not looking for war,” appearing to signal that it would not escalate tensions with the U.S. But he also said that Iran was prepared to respond if attacked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: San Francisco’s “Pro-Drug Culture”
description: The city’s addiction crisis has worsened quickly — and culture is a big factor.
content: For some San Franciscans, a drug crisis is just part of city living. They see people shooting up in front of their homes and businesses. They often find someone dozing on a sidewalk, high. Sometimes, they check for a pulse. “That’s how I found my first dead body,” said Adam Mesnick, owner of a local deli.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Is It Right to Have Students Raise Funds for a Team They Hope to Be On?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the integrity of a high school basketball team’s fund-raising campaign.
content: My nephew attends a large public high school in Florida. Recently, he was fund-raising for the school basketball team and asked me for a donation. He wasn’t on the team, I learned, but tryouts were happening, and he thought his chances were pretty good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Achauer
title: No Pain, No Gain? Your Body Would Like a Word.
description: Experts say it’s crucial to listen to your body to avoid injury. But what does that really mean, and how can you put it into practice?
content: As a sprint relay track cyclist on the U.S. Olympic Team, Joshua Hartman spends much of his training time lifting weights to build power and speed. In 2023, while trying to deadlift a load near the limit of his ability, he noticed that his form was off, and the weight wasn’t moving as quickly as he wanted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Federal Reserve Meets Wednesday. Here’s What to Watch.
description: Officials are likely to keep interest rates unchanged at the conclusion of their January meeting. Here’s a look at what might come next.
content: Federal Reserve officials will conclude their two-day meeting on Wednesday, and they are widely expected to keep interest rates steady at a two-decade high when they release their policy decision at 2 p.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carolyn Wilke
title: Parrots Use Their Beaks to Swing Like Monkeys
description: A study offers the latest evidence of the problem-solving prowess of the clever birds.
content: Rosy-faced lovebirds are charismatic, petite parrots. They also aren’t afraid to use their heads — literally — to get around an awkward situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Klinenberg
title: We Were Wrong About What Happened to America in 2020
description: The answer, only now coming into view, explains why that awful year still has us in its grip.
content: Covid numbers recently climbed again. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention once again reported monthly death tolls in the thousands. Mask mandates are back in New York City’s public medical facilities and nursing homes. The presidential race has kicked into gear and, just as in 2020, the stakes seem existential. It all makes me feel like I’m revisiting a past I never actually left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Piepenburg
title: Do Panic: Dario Argento’s Cinema
description: The Italian horror director is the subject of a new documentary and a film retrospective. But his artistry can be summed up in his feature directing debut, “The Bird With the Crystal Plumage.”
content: There’s a moment in “Dario Argento Panico,” a new documentary about the Italian horror movie maestro Dario Argento, that made me wonder if I’ve misunderstood why his assertively macabre and stylishly grotesque films so deeply give me the willies. It comes late in the film in Argento’s own words — word, actually — as he talks about what makes his scary movies scary.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Monkey Is Living ‘His Best Life’ on the Run in the Scottish Highlands
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 31, 2024.
content: “You would think we were chasing an international fugitive instead of an innocent monkey.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Biden Repays His Debt to South Carolina
description: The state was the home of his political resurrection four years ago.
content: It’s usually thankless work to be a state-level political operative. But not this year for Democrats in South Carolina.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: What the Fed’s Rate Moves Could Mean for Mortgages, Credit Cards and More
description: Higher rates benefit those who can save, but for borrowers, falling rates would reduce bills on credit cards, student loans and other forms of debt.
content: While the Federal Reserve is expected to keep its key interest rate unchanged on Wednesday, American households will want to know whether rate cuts are on the horizon, which could have meaningful implications for their monthly budgets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: One Big Reason Migrants Are Coming in Droves: They Believe They Can Stay
description: Seeking asylum has become the surest way for migrants to stay in the U.S. The underfunded immigration system can’t keep up, so cases languish for years.
content: For decades, single young men, mainly from Mexico and later Central America, did their best to sneak past U.S. border agents to reach Los Angeles, Atlanta and other places hungry for their labor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: There’s Always Been Trouble in ‘The Groves of Academe’
description: How a 1950s novel explains the crisis in higher education.
content: American higher education is in crisis. What else is new?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul and Amir Hamja
title: Leather and Lace for the Queen of Pop
description: Madonna fans served up style tributes to their idol on a New York stop of her tour.
content: Madonna performed at Madison Square Garden on Monday night as part of her Celebration Tour, a lavish stage spectacle devoted to her catalog of hits as the Queen of Pop. During “Like a Prayer,” she sang from a spinning carousel filled with jumbo crucifixes and shirtless men. When she performed “Vogue,” she invited Kelly Ripa onto the stage to join her in judging the ballroom moves of her dancers with scorecards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: A Stunningly Well-Preserved 600-Year-Old Gauntlet Is Found in Switzerland
description: The iron glove was found near a castle in Switzerland and saved from the effects of planned demolition. Who exactly wore it remains a mystery.
content: A medieval knight returns to a Swiss castle after a victorious battle. With a hearty whoop he tosses aside his prized gauntlets at the blacksmith shop. As he rushes off to a celebratory feast, they sit out of sight in a dark corner. Not too long after, a fire breaks out, the shop is destroyed and the gauntlets are lost for more than 600 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: What Elon Musk Could Lose After His Big Pay Deal Is Blocked
description: A Delaware court ruling on his $50 billion compensation plan at Tesla raises questions about corporate governance and more.
content: An unusual pay package that Tesla devised in 2018 helped make Elon Musk the world’s wealthiest individual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez, Josh Katz and Alicia Parlapiano
title: Can San Francisco Solve Its Drug Crisis? Five Things to Consider.
description: A comparison with Portugal’s approach to decriminalization shows why many liberal cities have struggled to match its success.
content: San Francisco is in the middle of a drug crisis. Overdose deaths reached a record high last year, topping 800. Public drug use is widespread in some neighborhoods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: ‘Destination Dupes’ and Other Ways to Save Money in 2024
description: Frugal strategies — like traveling where the dollar is strong and sampling unsung destinations — help make the most of your budget.
content: While others focus on New Year’s resolutions, my family and I come up with a dream list of where we want to go. Places we missed the previous year (Thailand and the Cook Islands) often get rolled over, but we always add new places (this year, South Korea) that can — with careful planning — be done affordably.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: A Biden Doctrine for the Middle East Is Forming. And It’s Big.
description: America’s approach to Iran, a Palestinian state and Saudi Arabia are at the heart of a possible strategic realignment in the Middle East.
content: There are two things I believe about the widening crisis in the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Frozen U.S. Spending for U.N. in Gaza Is Minimal, State Dept. Says
description: Just $300,000 is on hold after Israeli claims that UNRWA employees joined the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks, U.S. officials say.
content: The State Department downplayed the significance on Tuesday of its decision to pause funding for the main U.N. aid agency in Gaza, explaining that it had already provided virtually all the money allocated by Congress for that purpose and that the Biden administration hoped the matter could be resolved quickly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gonchar
title: Teach About Climate Change With 30 Graphs From The New York Times
description: A new collection to explore our planet’s warming oceans, intensifying storms and rising air temperatures, as well as its greenhouse gas emissions and climate solutions.
content: How can we help students really see climate change when it is a planet-wide process gradually unfolding over decades? Any given hurricane, prolonged drought or scorching hot day (or summer) might be more likely to occur because of the changing climate. But there will always be weather anomalies; just like in sports, records will be set.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gal Koplewitz
title: An Israeli Charity for Palestinians Grapples With Oct. 7 Attacks
description: Before the war, Road to Recovery helped bring sick Gazans to Israeli hospitals. Several of its volunteers died in the Hamas attacks, and donations to the group have slowed.
content: Nearly every week for a decade, Iri Kassel picked up sick Palestinian children at Israel’s Erez border crossing with Gaza and drove them with their guardians to Israeli hospitals for treatment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Carl Zimmer, Alex Stern, Jessica Cheung, Shannon Lin, Carlos Prieto, M.J. Davis Lin, Marc Georges, Chelsea Daniel, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: Is the Future of Medicine Hidden in Ancient DNA?
description: Genetic fragments from thousands of years ago are providing insights into illnesses such as multiple sclerosis and diabetes.
content: In a major advance in science, DNA from Bronze Age skeletons is providing clues to modern medical mysteries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: ‘We Are Not Very Far From an Explosion’
description: As the war grinds on in Gaza, settler attacks are rising — and Palestinian anger is growing.
content: One recent morning in Huwara, a Palestinian man maneuvered a front-end loader back and forth, clearing rocks and rubble that Israel Defense Forces soldiers had piled into a roadblock. Four young soldiers looked on, fingers tensed on triggers, as the machine’s claws heaved shattered masonry from clutching mud. A crowd of approving Palestinian onlookers gathered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Rubin Museum, Haven for Asian Art, to Close After 20 Years
description: It is the first major art museum in New York to close within recent memory. The museum had financial challenges and has faced accusations of displaying looted art.
content: The Rubin Museum of Art in Manhattan will shutter after two decades of championing its prized collection of art from Himalayan Asia, with leaders saying on Wednesday that they wanted to envision a modern museum without walls. But the museum, which will sell its building, was also facing financial challenges and had become a focal point in recent discussions about the history of religious objects being looted from Asian countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Robbins
title: Biogen Abandons Its Controversial Alzheimer’s Drug Aduhelm
description: The pharmaceutical company will give up its ownership rights to the drug and stop a clinical trial that had been aimed at confirming whether it works.
content: The drug maker Biogen said on Wednesday it would abandon its ownership rights to Aduhelm, an Alzheimer’s drug that had provoked fierce criticism of the company and regulators after it was approved based on weak evidence that it would help patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Which Sundance 2024 Movies Will Make It to Next Year’s Oscars?
description: A Jesse Eisenberg-Kieran Culkin film, along with performances by Saoirse Ronan and André Holland, may be on the ballot next year.
content: We’ve only just gotten this year’s Oscar nominations, but is it already time to begin looking ahead to next season?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: Some Major G.O.P. Donors Begin a Slow Turn Toward Trump
description: A meeting of the influential American Opportunity Alliance this week reflected weakening support for Nikki Haley in a previously Trump-resistant donor class.
content: Nikki Haley lost Iowa. Then she lost New Hampshire. Now, some of the biggest donors in the Republican Party — a Trump-resistant donor class that has fueled her candidacy for months — are at least opening the door to former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: auteur
description: This word has appeared in 71 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word auteur has appeared in 71 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 2 in “Beyoncé the Auteur Takes Center Stage in ‘Renaissance’” by Salamishah Tillet:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: With Fate of Ukraine’s Top General in Question, All Eyes Turn to Zelensky
description: Portraits of Gen. Valery Zaluzhny hang in coffee shops and bars inside Ukraine, but his strained relationship with President Volodymyr Zelensky may cost him his post.
content: He deftly defended his country in Europe’s largest ground war in decades, stalling Russia’s invasion and then pushing it back with everything at hand: natural barriers like rivers, aging weapons and lethal drones, trickery and elements of surprise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood
title: In His Second Sentencing in Two Days, Imran Khan Gets 14 Years
description: The sentences, just over a week before Pakistan’s national election, come as the former prime minister’s party has been battered by a crackdown.
content: Just a day after he was sentenced to a decade in prison, former Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan on Wednesday was ordered jailed for 14 years in a separate case, dealing him another heavy blow in his bitter feud with the country’s powerful military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Adams vs. Adams: New York’s Top Democrats Clash on City’s Path
description: Adrienne Adams, the speaker of the City Council, has become one of Mayor Eric Adams’s most powerful critics as he struggles with crises and low approval ratings.
content: As Mayor Eric Adams battles low poll ratings, a federal investigation and potential challengers to his re-election in New York City, a Democratic ally has emerged as an unexpected adversary: Adrienne Adams, the City Council speaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Reality, Art and Peloton Stars Party at the Whitney
description: Guests at the museum’s annual Art Party in New York City talk about A.I.’s role in making their work.
content: She had already trained for three hours earlier in the day, but that didn’t stop Robin Arzón, the Peloton instructor, from hitting the dance floor Tuesday evening in the cavernous lobby of the Whitney Museum of American Art in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Good Marriages Are Good. Bad Marriages Are, Well, Bad.
description: On luxury beliefs and why marriage isn’t a cure-all.
content: There’s an idea that’s been floating around for a few years that when it comes to marriage, wealthy elites hold luxury beliefs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: N.J. Transit Wants a Big Fare Increase. Riders Want Better Service.
description: Gov. Philip D. Murphy said that major improvements to the transit system on his watch justified the proposed 15 percent fare hike, but customers disagreed.
content: Unlike many of his fellow New Jerseyans, Ian Whelan seems too polite to broadcast his gripes about the state’s much-maligned commuter railroad. But a new plan to raise train fares by 15 percent set him off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Auction of Mandela Items Is Halted During South Africa Court Fight
description: While waiting for a court to decide whether Nelson Mandela’s belongings are considered national heritage, Guernsey’s said it had become clear that a sale would be “difficult.”
content: The New York auction house that was planning to sell several dozen of Nelson Mandela’s personal belongings next month suspended the event after a South African government agency filed court papers seeking to force the return of the items.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Anne Edwards, Best-Selling ‘Queen of Biography,’ Dies at 96
description: She profiled Vivien Leigh, Katharine Hepburn, Judy Garland, Barbra Streisand and Ronald Reagan. She also profiled herself, in two memoirs and an autobiography.
content: Anne Edwards, a prodigious and peripatetic author who published best-selling books about the actresses Vivien Leigh and Katharine Hepburn as well as 14 other celebrity biographies, eight novels, three children’s books, two memoirs and one autobiography, died on Jan. 20 in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 96.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: The Boston Symphony Plays a Sober ‘Lady Macbeth’
description: The orchestra, under Andris Nelsons, gave a clear and controlled concert performance of Shostakovich’s crushing opera at Carnegie Hall.
content: The Metropolitan Opera’s production of Shostakovich’s “Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk” is a garish explosion, its imagery drawn from cartoons and the Keystone Kops, its madcap energy never-ending. It’s fabulous, but the score can feel whooshed into a blender’s whirlwind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: New York Community Bancorp, Winner in Last Year’s Crisis, Takes a Hit
description: Shares of the small lender, which absorbed most of failing Signature Bank, collapsed after disappointing earnings report.
content: Less than a year ago, New York Community Bancorp looked like one of the big beneficiaries of a crisis among its peers when it swooped in to take over most of the assets of ailing Signature Bank and catapulted to over $100 billion in assets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Nichol and Jillian Weinberger
title: My Sister’s Murder Isn’t for Your Entertainment
description: True crime commodified my sister’s death. Then lawmakers weaponized it.
content: In 1993, Polly Klaas was kidnapped and murdered at the age of 12. Following her death, Polly’s tragic story became a plotline in true crime podcasts, TV shows and books. In this audio essay, Polly’s sister Annie Nichol argues that the popularization of true crime not only re-traumatized victims’ families but also helped create demand for “tough on crime” legislation. “Our legal system actually became more reactionary and more fixated on punishment and fundamentally less just,” she says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: Utah Sets Restrictions on Transgender People’s Bathroom Use
description: Under the new law, transgender people will be prohibited from using bathrooms in public schools and government-owned buildings that align with their gender identity, with few exceptions.
content: Utah will prohibit transgender people from using bathrooms in public schools and government-owned buildings that align with their gender identity, after Gov. Spencer Cox signed a bill on Tuesday imposing the restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dolnick
title: The Essential Alice Munro
description: The only prerequisite for reading the Nobel laureate, a master of short stories, is: having lived. Here’s where to start.
content: Before I’d read Alice Munro — when my knowledge of her amounted to an oafish word cloud (“older woman,” “Canadian,” “short stories”) — I imagined that the experience of reading her books, if I ever bothered to, would be like listening to classical music on fancy headphones in a college library: civilized, subtle, probably sleep-inducing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: The Apple Vision Pro Is a Marvel. But Who Will Buy It?
description: Parents, movie buffs and office workers might all succumb to the novelty of Apple’s new “spatial computing” device.
content: Last week, I was ushered by an Apple employee through a security gate, past a manicured lawn, down a flight of stairs and into a tastefully decorated faux living room inside the Steve Jobs Theater to get a preview of the company’s new Vision Pro headset.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: A Chocolate Fondue to Remember
description: This midcentury classic has a way of stirring up the past.
content: The summer after college, I worked briefly as a shoe model. By briefly, I mean that I was fired after one day. I had sublet a basement room somewhere in the hundreds on the West Side of Manhattan, and my belongings, mostly books, remained unpacked, in duct-taped boxes stacked around the bed. I had to crawl over them when I wanted to lie down, which was most of the time. I slept 14, 15 hours at a shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: With Aid Stalled, Ukraine Scrambles to Make Ends Meet
description: The government says it can juggle its finances for a few months, but warns of an economic crisis if Western assistance remains stuck.
content: Short of cash as well as personnel and equipment for its war against Russia, Ukraine’s government says it has cobbled together financing to last several months without long-stalled aid from the United States and Europe. But further delays would trigger an all-but-certain economic crisis, officials and analysts say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: They Took Their Horses to the Swiss Alps for Snow Polo. They Got Slush Instead.
description: In St. Moritz, a ski resort town that revolves around winter tourism, high temperatures made full matches impossible and raised concerns about the future.
content: The horses were all set. The players were ready. As were the spectators, many of whom had arrived at the idyllic winter wonderland of St. Moritz, Switzerland, with soft fur coats and stylish moon boots. Everything was in place for the Snow Polo World Cup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang and Mike Isaac
title: Meta Rejected Efforts to Improve Children’s Safety, Documents Show
description: Lawmakers released internal emails detailing the company’s failed efforts to add staff to focus on the online safety of minors, hours before a hearing on the topic.
content: Hours before Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Meta, was set to testify on Wednesday about child safety online, lawmakers released internal documents showing how his company had rejected calls to bulk up on resources to combat the problem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Adam Goldman
title: China Is Targeting U.S. Infrastructure and Could ‘Wreak Chaos,’ F.B.I. Says
description: In testimony before Congress, Christopher A. Wray, the agency’s director, said Beijing was preparing to sow chaos if disputes with the United States flared into conflict.
content: Christopher A. Wray, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, warned on Wednesday that China was ramping up an extensive hacking operation geared at taking down the United States’ power grid, oil pipelines and water systems in the event of a conflict over Taiwan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps and Sean Keenan
title: Platoonmates Killed in Jordan Saw Army Service as a Life Ladder
description: Two of the American troops killed on Sunday were, like many young Black women, drawn to the military for the opportunities and level playing field it offered.
content: At a dusty military base in northeastern Jordan, Specialist Kennedy Sanders drove bulldozers and road graders. When she had free time, she liked to spend it knitting, or feeding her sneaker-head habit by shopping online for rare pairs of Nike Dunks that she would make her mother unbox for her over FaceTime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: House Passes Bipartisan Tax Bill, but Election-Year Politics Complicate Its Path
description: The House approved a $78 billion tax package Wednesday with a large bipartisan margin. The effort is a test of whether a dysfunctional Congress can pass major legislation in an election year.
content: The House gave broad bipartisan approval on Wednesday to a $78 billion bill that would expand the child tax credit and restore a set of corporate tax breaks, a rare feat in an election year by a Congress that has labored to legislate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ella Riley-Adams
title: Pet Beds That Might Be Nicer Than Your Own
description: Embroidered cushions and ruffled slipcovers are on the rise as designers turn their attention to an often-ignored piece of furniture.
content: The Wrightsman Galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art are full of the gilded furniture and ornate chandeliers that typify the decorative arts of 17th- and 18th-century France. Wandering the rooms as a child, the designer Adam Charlap Hyman, 34, noticed one piece in particular: a blue velvet-upholstered doghouse — or niche de chien — that belonged to Marie Antoinette. Its arched doorway was gold rimmed, its interior lined with striped silk. “I always loved that dog folly and thought it would be fun to make a little world for a dog that could also go into one of our interiors,” Charlap Hyman says, referring to the rooms he creates with the architect Andre Herrero, 34. The pair recently produced a scalloped wicker dog bed frame with spherical steel feet, as well as a pair of ruched lilac and pink imitation-taffeta slipcovers to beautify a classic metal-barred crate. They initially created the ruched designs as a wedding present for a Los Angeles couple whose bedroom they’d decorated with leopard-print carpet and wallpaper patterned with hanging vines. “It was definitely a more-is-more situation, so those dog beds felt at home,” Charlap Hyman says. Now, the firm is selling a made-to-measure version for others looking to add whimsy to an object that’s typically an eyesore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Who Will Have the Biggest Grammy Night?
description: Taylor Swift and SZA could make history at the 66th annual awards on Sunday night, where young women dominate the nominations, and revered older artists will take the stage.
content: The 66th annual Grammy Awards on Sunday are poised to be a celebration of a dominant year for women in pop music, with female stars like SZA, Taylor Swift, Olivia Rodrigo and Billie Eilish facing off in the major categories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang and David McCabe
title: ‘Your Product Is Killing People’: Tech Leaders Denounced Over Child Safety
description: Senators criticized the chief executives of Meta, TikTok, Snap, X and Discord for not doing enough to prevent child sexual abuse online, amid rising fears over how the platforms affect youths.
content: Lawmakers on Wednesday denounced the chief executives of Meta, TikTok, X, Snap and Discord, accusing them of creating “a crisis in America” by willfully ignoring the harmful content against children on their platforms, as concerns over the effect of technology on youths have mushroomed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Brother-in-Law Gets Free Child Care From His Parents. Why Don’t We?
description: Frustrated that she and her partner live too far away from his parents to reap the benefits of free grandparental supervision, a reader wonders how to broach her feelings of being cheated.
content: My partner’s parents have been financially dependent on him and his brother for 10 years. They are unable to work. Still, they have provided free child care for my brother-in-law’s two children for the past five years. Meanwhile, my partner has been paying half of his parents’ living expenses. I’ve stayed out of these arrangements; my partner and I keep our finances separate. But now that we have a baby of our own — and his parents live too far away to provide child care — I am resentful that my partner has been effectively subsidizing his brother’s child care rather than saving money for ours. I think his brother is taking advantage of us. My partner is very sensitive about this; he doesn’t think grandparents should be compensated for child care. How can I approach this subject without creating tension?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: He’s Teaching Others to Run, Because He Can’t Do It Anymore
description: With long Covid ending his own days as an endurance athlete, Matt Fitzgerald opened the doors of his home, creating a fantasy camp for runners with a dream.
content: Never one to waste a spare moment, Matt Fitzgerald clambered into the second row of his Mazda CX-90 on a recent weekday morning and cracked open his MacBook so that he could work on another book.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold, Billy Witz and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Suit Seeks to Block N.C.A.A. Limits on Athletic Donors
description: The attorneys general in Tennessee and Virginia are asserting that the N.C.A.A. has no right to stop boosters of college sports teams from paying players.
content: The attorneys general of Tennessee and Virginia filed suit on Wednesday against the N.C.A.A., saying the body that regulates college athletics has no right to block the increasingly common practice of wealthy boosters paying to attract top recruits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Anusha Bayya
title: They Said They Weren’t Murderers. After Four Decades, the Courts Agreed.
description: Eric Smokes and David Warren were convicted of killing a French tourist in a mugging. Until 2022, prosecutors fought their attempts to prove their innocence.
content: Minutes into New Year’s Day 1987, a French couple visiting New York fell behind their companions while walking in Midtown Manhattan’s holiday crowds and were attacked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario and Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Universal Music Group Threatens to Remove Music From TikTok
description: The company has been renegotiating the contract that licenses its vast catalog of songs to the social media platform. The agreement expires on Wednesday.
content: Universal Music Group, the world’s largest music company, said it would revoke the licenses for its vast catalog of songs from TikTok after its current contract expires on Wednesday if the two companies could not reach a new deal addressing Universal’s concerns over artist compensation, artificial intelligence and other issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: PGA Tour Raises $1.5 Billion From Group of U.S. Investors
description: The move, which involves the Fenway Sports Group, raises questions about whether a deal to combine forces with Saudi Arabia’s sovereign fund is still necessary.
content: The PGA Tour announced on Wednesday that it had reached a deal to raise at least $1.5 billion from a group of U.S. investors, a move that raises new questions about whether a proposed alliance with a rival tour backed by Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund will come to fruition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: In Northern Ireland, a Knotty Brexit Problem Is on the Brink of Being Solved
description: Four years after Britain officially left the E.U., the U.K. government on Wednesday published the details of a deal to restore the power-sharing government in Belfast.
content: Almost two years of political gridlock. Decision-making paralyzed. Rising tension in a place where peace remains fragile even after the end of decades of sectarian strife.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Farrell
title: A Start-Up Secret: Executives’ ‘11th-Hour’ Pay Bumps
description: Just before going public, companies price stock options at steep discounts — and take steps to obscure them, a new research paper finds.
content: Public companies must abide by strict rules when granting stock options to their top executives, including pricing them where the company’s shares are trading on the day they are granted and disclosing them swiftly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
title: Thai Court Rules Progressive Party’s Reform Push Violated Constitution
description: Critics call the verdict against the popular Move Forward Party, which hoped to scale back a royal defamation law, another blatant attempt to block the people’s will.
content: The most popular political party in Thailand won its following last year, and the ire of the conservative establishment, by campaigning to end military rule and to weaken the draconian law that prohibits criticism of the country’s monarchy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Chita Rivera Lived to Entertain. Here Are 9 Memorable Performances.
description: A quadruple threat, Rivera could make a lasting impression in minutes, whether onstage or onscreen. These videos illustrate why.
content: Chita Rivera, who died on Tuesday at the age of 91, was known for her extraordinary artistry. Yet, it is hard to comprehend the full scope of her talent because, like so many Broadway performers of her generation, much of her best work was not captured on-screen. Her Anita in the landmark 1957 Broadway production of “West Side Story”? Rita Moreno took it on in the Hollywood adaptation. Rose in the hit “Bye Bye Birdie,” from 1960? That role went to Janet Leigh in the movie. Only in 1969 did Rivera make her feature-film debut, in “Sweet Charity,” almost two decades after her Broadway debut. Thankfully, we have variety shows, TV specials and unofficial fan videos to help us patch together a compelling video portrait. Her life force bursts through in every second.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Taylor Swift, Donald Trump and the Right’s Abnormality Problem
description: Girl meets boy and falls in love. Conservatives are furious.
content: There was a brief period in the later part of the Covid-19 pandemic, between the moment when Glenn Youngkin swept into the Virginia governorship and the full political return of Donald Trump, when I became convinced that American liberalism was headed for a truly epochal defeat in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Why So Many People Can’t Get That Galliano Show Out of Their Heads
description: In celebrating John Galliano’s “return to his roots,” have we somehow missed the point?
content: There is a certain irony to the fact that of all the shows that took place during couture last week, the one designed to be the most off-line — the one conceived as an in-person experience rather than as a simple catwalk — is the one that ended up going the most viral.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: Chicago Passes Gaza Cease-Fire Resolution in Israel-Hamas War
description: The passions ignited by the war in Gaza have reverberated through American politics, but the issue has been particularly contentious in Chicago and its suburbs.
content: The Chicago City Council voted on Wednesday to approve a resolution calling for an immediate cease-fire in the war between Israel and Hamas, making it the largest city in the United States to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: New Mexico Will Not Charge Officers Who Fatally Shot Man at Wrong Address
description: The New Mexico Department of Justice said the officers in Farmington, N.M., did not use excessive force when they shot Robert Dotson because he answered the door with a raised gun.
content: No criminal charges will be filed against three New Mexico police officers who went to the wrong address while responding to a domestic violence call last year and fatally shot the armed homeowner who came to the door, state officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: News Outlet Blames Photoshop for Making Australian Lawmaker’s Photo More Revealing
description: 9News apologized for the edited photo of the member of state Parliament, Georgie Purcell, which it said was a result of “automation by Photoshop.”
content: A lawmaker in the Australian state of Victoria sat down to watch the nightly news on Monday, expecting to see herself featured as a prominent opponent of duck hunting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Boeing Suspends Financial Outlook as It Focuses on Safety
description: The manufacturer is under pressure to improve quality control after a panel blew off a 737 Max 9 plane during an Alaska Airlines flight this month.
content: Boeing said on Wednesday that it would not provide a full-year financial forecast, the clearest indication yet that the company is trying to assure customers that it is prioritizing safety amid growing concerns about its popular 737 Max jets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing and Peter Eavis
title: Elon Musk’s $50 Billion Tesla Pay Was Struck Down. What Happens Next?
description: The company’s board of directors will now decide whether to appeal the decision, change where Tesla is incorporated or negotiate a new pay package.
content: A Delaware judge’s decision to void the pay package that helped make Elon Musk the world’s richest person leaves Tesla’s board of directors with some difficult decisions to make.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Your Energy Playlist
description: What would you put on a playlist designed to get you moving?
content: At the beginning of this month, the Well section asked Ahmir K. Thompson, also known as Questlove, to curate a playlist for their Six-Day Energy Challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Major Layoffs at Fair Fight, Voting Rights Group Founded by Stacey Abrams
description: The cuts would decimate a high-profile liberal group that was once a fund-raising powerhouse for Democrats.
content: Fair Fight, the liberal voting rights group founded by Stacey Abrams, is laying off most of its staff and scaling back its efforts in response to mounting debts incurred by court battles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Federal Judge Dismisses Disney Lawsuit Against DeSantis
description: The company had claimed that the Florida governor and his allies violated its First Amendment rights by taking over a special tax district that governs Walt Disney World.
content: In a significant victory for Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida, a federal judge on Wednesday threw out a lawsuit filed by the Walt Disney Company claiming that Mr. DeSantis and his allies violated the First Amendment by taking over a special tax district that encompasses Walt Disney World.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Claire Fu
title: China’s Censorship Dragnet Targets Critics of the Economy
description: As Beijing struggles with a slumping stock market and a collapsing real estate sector, commentary and even financial analysis it deems negative are blocked.
content: China’s top intelligence agency issued an ominous warning last month about an emerging threat to the country’s national security: Chinese people who criticize the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Sinema, Her Fund-Raising Fading, Faces Ticking Clock on Senate Decision
description: The Arizona senator is behind schedule on deciding whether to run for re-election as an independent, and she raised only $600,000 in the last quarter of 2023.
content: Senator Kyrsten Sinema is behind schedule in making a decision about whether to seek re-election in Arizona. She’s also running out of time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Nikki Haley Goes After Trump and Biden in ‘Grumpy Old Men’ Campaign
description: Ms. Haley has recently shifted her strategy, casting Donald Trump, 77, and President Biden, 81, as part of the same bygone era of politician.
content: Two curmudgeonly old rivals, reclusive spendthrifts, are marching toward a showdown that a lot of people really wish wasn’t happening. If that is the plot of a slapstick comedy, it’s also the latest knock from Nikki Haley on former President Donald J. Trump and President Biden as she fights for oxygen ahead of the Republican primary in South Carolina on Feb. 24.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Fed Holds Interest Rates Steady and Is Not Quite Ready to Cut Them.
description: Federal Reserve officials, seeking more progress on the fight against inflation, hinted that their next move will be a cut in interest rates — just not yet.
content: Federal Reserve officials held interest rates at their highest level in more than two decades at their first meeting of 2024 and hinted that their next move will be to lower borrowing costs — even as policymakers made clear they are not yet ready to make that cut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Fox News to Taylor Swift: ‘Don’t Get Involved in Politics!’
description: The prospect of the pop megastar’s endorsing President Biden in the 2024 election has irked conservative stars on the cable network.
content: Taylor Swift has not uttered a word about the 2024 presidential election. But the mere prospect that the pop superstar could endorse President Biden has sent conservatives on Fox News into conniptions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Adam Rasgon and Thomas Fuller
title: Donors Rally Behind UNRWA, as U.N. Seeks to Restore Confidence
description: The U.S. envoy to the United Nations urged it to “take quick and decisive action” over Israeli allegations that 12 employees of UNRWA, the main aid agency for Palestinians, had taken part in the Oct. 7 attack.
content: After days of sharply criticizing the U.N. agency charged with assisting Palestinian civilians, donor countries signaled on Wednesday that they would continue to support the organization under the right conditions and stressed its essential role in delivering lifesaving aid as widespread starvation and disease loom in the war-ravaged Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green
title: Biden to Visit the Site of Train Derailment in East Palestine, Ohio
description: President Biden has been under pressure to make the trip since the toxic spill nearly a year ago, as residents express frustration with the federal response.
content: President Biden will visit East Palestine, Ohio, in February to mark the first anniversary of the toxic derailment that plunged the small community into a health and environmental crisis, the White House announced on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Impeachment Case Against Mayorkas Ignores Government’s Immigration Powers
description: House Republicans have charged President Biden’s homeland security secretary with breaking the law by failing to enforce border mandates, but statute gives him wide authority to address immigration.
content: House Republicans’ impeachment case against Alejandro N. Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, boils down to a simple allegation: that he has broken the law by refusing to enforce immigration statutes that aim to prevent migrants from entering the United States without authorization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Six takeaways from a contentious online child safety hearing.
description: Senators aggressively questioned executives from major tech companies, especially Meta and TikTok, while Mark Zuckerberg spoke directly to victims’ families.
content: After a series of tense exchanges between senators and tech executives that clocked in at just under four hours, the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on online child safety came to an end on Wednesday with no clear resolutions in sight. The audience included several family members of victims, who cheered as senators berated the executives and listened stoically as Mark Zuckerberg, the chief executive of Meta, addressed the crowd directly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Bipartisan Bill Aims to Protect Children Online
description: A bill backed by dozens of senators would require platforms take “reasonable measures” to shield children from bullying, harassment, sexual exploitation, anorexia, self-harm and predatory marketing.
content: Members of Congress have introduced a number of different bills intended to boost protections for children and teenagers online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson and Emmanuel Morgan
title: Tributes Pour in to Chita Rivera on Broadway, Where She Reigned
description: Onstage and off, she was celebrated as a pathbreaking triple-threat who left a huge legacy in musical theater and dance.
content: Chita Rivera created several memorable Broadway characters that are now considered part of the canon, including the role of Velma Kelly in the original production of “Chicago.” So when the cast of the long-running Broadway revival took to the stage of the Ambassador Theater in New York on Tuesday night just a few hours after her death was announced, it was only natural that they would pay tribute to her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Is High School a Good Time to Train for a Career?
description: If a full-time job with a good salary were yours at graduation, would you start preparing for it now?
content: What career or careers interest you? Do you know what path will take you to your dream job? Will it require training, experience, a college degree or perhaps additional degrees, internships and so on?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Barron, Lynn Levy, Daniel Ramirez and Margaret Lyons
title: A Beloved ’90s TV Show Finally Comes to Streaming
description: Our TV critic on the joy and melancholy of “Northern Exposure.”
content: “Northern Exposure” premiered on CBS in 1990. Over the next six years, it drew millions of viewers, won a raft of Emmys and adorned the cover of multiple issues of TV Guide. But despite its success decades ago, “Northern Exposure” wasn’t widely available on streaming platforms until recently. Our TV critic Margaret Lyons considers how being out of circulation affected the show’s legacy, and the joys of rediscovering this classic series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Think the Baby Bust Was Bad Before? Just Look at It Now.
description: We need to appreciate just how severe the global decline in birthrates is getting.
content: The baby bust that we all know about has gotten worse in a way that isn’t yet widely understood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Sauerbrey
title: Germany Has Finally Woken Up
description: Any complacency about the threat of the far right has been shattered.
content: The ground was icy as my partner, my son and I made our way to the center of Berlin two Sundays ago. Still, as we joined about 100,000 others who had gathered there to protest right-wing extremism, it felt cozy — both in a literal and in a metaphorical sense. The mass of human bodies created a microclimate that made it bearable to be outside in the frosty Berlin dark for a couple of hours. And it was also warming to see this many people turn out to defend our democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela J. Lamas
title: When a Cure Comes Too Late
description: Future generations will see breakthroughs that cure many kinds of diseases. But where does that leave current patients?
content: Tyler Parish thinks of himself as “the last dinosaur.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $950,000 Homes in Indiana, Pennsylvania and Washington
description: A Tudor Revival house in Indianapolis, a Colonial Revival home in Lancaster and an updated Craftsman bungalow in Walla Walla.
content: This home is in the Meridian-Kessler neighborhood, less than a mile from a number of popular bars and restaurants, including a jazz club, a pub housed in a 1933 building and a barbecue spot with a beer garden. It is also close to Butler University, a private school with around 4,500 undergraduate students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Tanis
title: The Greenest Dinner Party You’ve Ever Had
description: Thrill your guests with a double celery salad, quick mussels in an herby butter sauce and pistachio-almond cookies from David Tanis.
content: Both celery root and mussels are at their best right now, so here’s a bright-green menu that welcomes them — a cool weather meal with verve and brightness, best eaten near the warmth of a fire or reasonable facsimile thereof.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel Breaks Down MAGA’s Super Bowl Conspiracy Theories
description: Is the N.F.L. rigged? Is Taylor Swift a psy-op? Kimmel says that “this nonsense is now everywhere your angry grandpa goes.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Will Taylor, SZA or Olivia Win Big at the Grammys?
description: A breakdown of the major categories and most interesting competitions at the 66th annual awards on Sunday.
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on the 2024 Grammy Awards, which will take place on Sunday. The hosts discuss who is likely to win (and who deserves to win) in the major competitions — album of the year, record of the year, song of the year and best new artist — as well as awards in the country, rap, pop and Latin categories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer
title: Silicon Valley Battles States Over New Online Safety Laws for Children
description: Lawsuits filed by NetChoice, which represents companies including TikTok and Meta, have stalled protection efforts in three states.
content: Last summer, Ohio enacted a social media statute that would require Instagram, Snapchat, TikTok and YouTube to get a parent’s consent before permitting children under age 16 to use their platforms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danyel  Smith
title: The World Needs Love. Hallmark Is Cashing in.
description: When more people are watching the Hallmark Channel than CNN, you know we’ve reached a new level of interpersonal isolation.
content: In this lull between perhaps the most successful slate of the Hallmark Channel’s Countdown to Christmas films ever and the Jane Austen-drenched debut of Hallmark’s Loveuary 2024, it’s time to admit that Hallmark movies are actually just Hollywood movies — and specifically rom-coms. Straight couples dance, in well-lit venues, to the music of real instruments. Wrenching decisions are suffered through. Misunderstandings abound. Soulful kisses are for denouements. Happy endings feel required by law. Call it vapid if you will, but the culture of the Hallmark universe has been around since the 16th century, when a shrew apparently needed to be tamed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Orlando Mayorquin
title: Jean Carnahan, 90, First Woman to Represent Missouri in U.S. Senate, Dies
description: Ms. Carnahan was appointed to the seat after her husband was posthumously elected to it just weeks after he was killed in a plane crash in 2000.
content: Jean Carnahan, who in 2001 became the first woman to represent Missouri in the U.S. Senate after being appointed to fill her husband’s seat following his posthumous election, died on Tuesday in St. Louis County, Mo. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: The Farmers’ Protests Have Become a Wildfire. He Was the Spark.
description: Jérôme Bayle had enough of the hardships of French farming, so he blocked a highway with friends. Hundreds of other farmers have followed suit.
content: Jérôme Bayle had spent seven nights on a major French highway, leading a group of aggrieved farmers in protest, when the prime minister arrived, dressed in his Parisian blue suit and tie, to thank them for “making France proud” and announced he would meet their demands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Two Big Storms Are Coming to California
description: The atmospheric rivers could lead to flooding, mudslides and road closures over the next week.
content: No matter where you are in California, big storms are headed your way over the next several days. Forecasters are warning of back-to-back atmospheric rivers that could lead to flooding, mudslides and road closures between today and Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Israel raided a West Bank hospital.
content: Israeli soldiers raided the Ibn Sina Specialized Hospital in the northern West Bank city of Jenin, killing a Hamas commander. The raid took place as Israel confirmed that it had begun pumping seawater into the vast Hamas tunnel network beneath Gaza to flush out militants and had renewed fighting in northern Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Thielking
title: Don’t Let Your Winter Walk End Up on a Blooper Reel
description: How to stroll with confidence in icy weather.
content: Maybe it was the wintry morning when I stepped out of the carpool van, hit an icy patch and went skidding on my backside toward the doors of my middle school as my classmates looked on. Or the day I stood on my front porch waving goodbye to a friend and watched in terror as she slid all the way down my frozen front steps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chrystel Oloukoï
title: An Artist Who Uses Plants as Camouflage
description: At the Guggenheim in New York, Joiri Minaya's digital collages reveal the power of concealment.
content: At the Guggenheim in New York, Joiri Minaya's digital collages reveal the power of concealment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: What’s in Our Queue? Mark Rothko and More
description: I’m an international correspondent for The New York Times. Here are five things I’ve been enjoying recently.
content: I’m an international correspondent for The New York Times. Here are five things I’ve been enjoying recently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones and Bea Malsky
title: Track the Latest Atmospheric Rivers to Hit California and the Pacific Northwest
description: Use these maps to follow the storm’s forecast and impact.
content: Use these maps to follow the storm’s forecast and impact.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller, Sarah Mervosh and Francesca Paris
title: Students Are Making a ‘Surprising’ Rebound From Pandemic Closures. But Some May Never Catch Up.
description: The first detailed nationwide data on schools’ recovery shows that achievement gaps have widened, with the poorest students the furthest behind.
content: The first detailed nationwide data on schools’ recovery shows that achievement gaps have widened, with the poorest students the furthest behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Paik
title: Why Tourists Have Been Stranded Near Machu Picchu
description: Demonstrators protesting a new ticketing system blocked access to Peru’s most-visited site and threw rocks at police officers, who fired tear gas into the crowd.
content: Demonstrators protesting a new ticketing system blocked access to Peru’s most-visited site and threw rocks at police officers, who fired tear gas into the crowd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Fed Wants More ‘Good Data’ Before Cutting Interest Rates, Powell Says
description: After the Federal Reserve announced that interest rates would remain unchanged, Jerome H. Powell, the Fed’s chair, signaled that cuts could come this year — though not by the central bank’s next meeting.
content: After the Federal Reserve announced that interest rates would remain unchanged, Jerome H. Powell, the Fed’s chair, signaled that cuts could come this year — though not by the central bank’s next meeting.
source.name: The New York Times
